fact_list.fact_text: How you drive and treat your vehicle can significantly affect fuel consumption and emissions.
Practicing eco-driving can reduce fuel consumption by up to 10% on average over time.
By observing a few simple eco-driving steps, you can reduce fuel use and vehicular emissions.
Eco-driving refers to handling oneâ€™s vehicle to promote fuel economy and reduce emissions.
Eco-driving includes vehicle maintenance, on-road driver behaviour, and route selection.
Eco-driving can lower vehicle fuel consumption and environmental impact through simple driving practices.
Idling engines waste fuel, generate unnecessary pollution, and cause fumes and noise nuisance.
Under the Environmental Protection and Management Regulations, leaving a vehicle engine running when stationary for non-traffic reasons is an offense.
Offenders of stationary engine idling rules are liable to a fine of up to $5,000 if convicted in court.
Modern engines reach their optimal temperature faster when driven at moderate speeds upon starting.
A well-maintained vehicle is more fuel efficient and emits less pollution on the road.
Correctly inflated tyres help reduce drag, improve fuel economy, and reduce pollution.
Carrying excess weight in a vehicle increases fuel consumption and emissions.
